Technonationalism and neorealism perspectives support this reading, noting the unprecedented scale of reciprocal escalation and the US default to 'over-control,' regardless of technical imperfections or industry objections. Furthermore, it is clear from the group’s analysis and news synthesis that a 'good enough' action—such as a targeted software restriction for China or other adversaries—will suffice for question resolution. Concerns about definitional ambiguity and minor procedural lag are heavily outweighed by the overwhelming evidence of political will, clear executive/bureaucratic pathway, and ongoing crisis escalation. The main uncertainty—scope or last-minute delay—now appears so marginal that, barring an unforeseeable bureaucratic mishap, the probability is not just high but extremely high.

Political Science (Punctuated Equilibriu.reasoning_for_revised_probability: The deliberation strongly highlighted the frequency and speed of US unilateral action in similar past circumstances, especially when facing direct, public escalation from China (e.g., 2022 chip controls, cyber tools). Multiple forecasters from both legal and national security backgrounds asserted that official enactment (not full coverage or global efficacy) is the relevant threshold—making the procedural or industry drag I previously weighted less important. Credible reporting of imminent bans, the scope for rapid interim or EAR Supplement actions, and the consistent history of prior punctuated regulatory leaps all point to a higher probability of action within the 2.5 month window. In light of these arguments, I now judge the odds of at least some generative AI software export control being enacted by Dec 31, 2025 as high.

Political Science (Policy Diffusion).reasoning_for_revised_probability: After reviewing the group deliberation, I see a clear, near-consensus convergence among domain experts that tilts even more heavily toward a 'Yes.' The modestly lower forecasts (such as Political Science - Punctuated Equilibrium Theory at 68% and Export Control Law - Wassenaar Arrangement Compliance at 78%) were sharply critiqued for underweighting the speed and inevitability of bureaucratic action under crisis, especially given the explicit and repeated references in news sources to imminent or already enacted 'critical software' controls. There is strong, well-defended logic that the US policy machinery, in this environment, routinely defaults to rapid, even if imperfect, control enactment when a major geopolitical rival escalates. My own forecast already integrated the key policy diffusion logic, but I now see that the potential for regulatory improvisation and the overwhelming political consensus for fast action are likely to overcome definitional or enforcement issues. The major risk is definition slippage (whether the enacted controls will clearly reference generative AI in a way that meets the Metaculus/contest resolution), but the signal that at least some explicit rule will emerge is overwhelming. Therefore, I will revise upward to align more with the top cluster of group assessments.

Science and Technology Studies (Technona.reasoning_for_revised_probability: Phase 2 deliberation affirmed the central logic of my initial forecast: the technonationalist frame, tit-for-tat escalation, and mounting bipartisan political pressure create a highly conducive environment for the enactment (not just proposal) of US export controls on generative AI software before the end of 2025. Dialogue with others, especially the defenses of the Neorealist and Dual Use perspectives, strengthens the case that regulatory drag and industry resistance are historically overcome when security logics dominate. However, critiques of the highest-confidence (91%) forecasts point out potential issues: regulatory ambiguity over 'generative AI', the possibility of industry lobbying causing last-minute legal narrowing, and the risk of public 'critical software' bans not explicitly covering generative AI within the narrow timeframe required for YES resolution. These headwinds suggest a very high—but not near-certain—probability. I see no compelling argument to significantly lower the probability, given the reporting of imminent or recently enacted controls and the political salience of matching Chinese escalation.

question_details.title: Will the US enact export controls for some generative AI software before 2026?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2023-05-17 15:19:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/17102). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

As of May 2023, US law does not have export controls on the sale of software services that include powerful generative AI. As such, OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, and Microsoft can sell LLM-assisted document writing, image generation, video generation, etc. to enterprises worldwide (up to more general export controls not focused on AI.)

In Oct 2022, the [US implemented export controls](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_New_Export_Controls_on_Advanced_Computing_and_Semiconductors_to_China), that, roughly speaking, bans export of semiconductors that involve US in their manufacturing chain to China.

As the capabilities of generative AI systems grow, and as enterprise customers learn more how to extract certain types of knowledge (e.g. how to create Deep Fakes or create armies of online bots), one way US policymakers might address risks would be to apply exports control to software that are similar to the export controls for hardware used for training AI.

`{"format":"metac_closes_in_period","info":{"post_id":17102,"question_id":17102}}`
question_details.resolution_criteria: This question resolves as **YES** if, by Dec 31 2025, the US imposes export controls on some generative AI software, and **NO** otherwise.
question_details.fine_print:
The export controls need not be specifically to China - anything under the standard export regime of the US would qualify.

The export controls must be specifically related to AI that can generate content. It is not sufficient if software produced by Microsoft or OpenAI cannot be exported to certain countries for other reasons - such as export bans on all software, or on all commercial products sold to certain countries.

These need to be actual export controls, as per the 2022 controls on semiconductors. Taxes or trade deals are not considered here.

Here are the relevant news articles:

**3 Big Mistakes for Artificial Intelligence (AI) Growth Stock Investors to Avoid in 2026**
On October 10, 2025, the Nasdaq Composite suffered a 3.6% decline, its worst session since April amid heightened U.S.-China trade tensions. The sell-off followed U.S. threats to impose a 100% tariff on Chinese imports in response to China's tightened export controls on rare-earth minerals and magnets—critical materials for semiconductors and AI-related technologies. On October 12, 2025, reports confirmed China would not back down from these escalating trade threats. The article warns AI growth stock investors preparing for 2026 to avoid three key mistakes. First, over-concentration in a single segment of the AI value chain: for example, investing in Nvidia (NASDAQ: NVDA), Broadcom, and Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) may appear diversified, but all rely heavily on the same major customer—OpenAI—which is building 10 gigawatts of data centers. A cut in OpenAI’s spending could negatively impact all three. Second, investing in semiconductor equipment suppliers like Applied Materials, Lam Research, and ASML, which serve the same large customers—Taiwan Semiconductor, Samsung Electronics, and Intel—means a reduction in spending by any one of them could ripple through the entire equipment sector. Third, overexposure to cloud computing giants—Amazon Web Services, Microsoft Azure, Google Cloud (Alphabet), and Oracle—while these companies benefit from AI demand, they also serve broader corporate computing and storage needs; a slowdown in AI investment or a broader economic downturn could reduce demand across their platforms. The article emphasizes that while market sell-offs can create buying opportunities, avoiding structural portfolio risks is critical to long-term success.
Original language: en
Publish date: October 17, 2025 11:45 AM
Source:[Yahoo! Finance](https://finance.yahoo.com/news/3-big-mistakes-artificial-intelligence-003000786.html)

**Wall Street Journal: Beijing’s Rare Earth Strategy Mirrors U.S. Tactics in 'Return the Favor' Approach**
According to an article published by The Wall Street Journal on October 15, 2025, Beijing is using rare earth export controls as a geopolitical tool in a manner strikingly similar to U.S. strategies, mirroring American actions that have long restricted China’s tech sector through semiconductor dominance. The article describes China’s approach as a modern 'revenge in kind'—akin to the Chinese proverb 'to return the same treatment received.' Jacob Gunter, analyst at Germany’s Mercator Institute for China Studies, identifies three key parallels: First, China’s Ministry of Commerce recently mandated that any product containing rare earth elements accounting for 0.1% or more of its final value must comply with Chinese laws—paralleling the U.S. Foreign Direct Product Rule (FDPR) and potentially extending global reach. Second, China has implemented a 'Chinese person rule' restricting unapproved Chinese citizens from participating in overseas rare earth activities, mirroring U.S. restrictions on Americans assisting China’s semiconductor industry. Third, China’s new regulations specifically target core segments of the global tech industry, including advanced chips below 14 nanometers and AI technologies with military applications—directly responding to U.S. export bans. The commentary suggests China aims to demonstrate its supply chain dominance and adopt an 'equal retaliation' posture. However, a spokesperson for China’s Ministry of Commerce, He Yongqian, stated on October 16, 2025, that China’s export controls are based on a sound legal framework and are not targeted at any specific country, with compliant civilian applications still eligible for approval.
Original language: zh
Publish date: October 16, 2025 11:04 PM
Source:[ETtoday新聞雲](https://www.ettoday.net/news/20251017/3051608.htm)

**AISN#64: New AGI Definition and Senate Bill Would Establish Liability for AI Harms -- LessWrong**
The AI Safety Newsletter by the Center for AI Safety highlights key developments in AI policy and safety. Senators Dick Durbin (D-Ill) and Josh Hawley (R-Mo) introduced the AI LEAD Act, which would establish federal product liability for AI systems, enabling individuals harmed by AI to sue companies. The act defines liability for failures in design, warnings, warranties, or defective conditions, and prohibits companies from limiting liability via contracts. It also requires foreign AI developers to register agents in the U.S. and allows states to enact stricter safety laws. Meanwhile, China has announced new export controls on rare earth metals and EV battery manufacturing equipment, effective November 8 and December 1, respectively. These controls could disrupt global AI and defense supply chains, as China dominates rare earth production—critical for semiconductors, AI hardware, and military systems. The U.S. responded with a proposed 100% additional tariff on Chinese goods and export controls on critical software. Analysts warn aggressive enforcement could trigger a U.S. economic downturn. In AI definitions, a group including Dan Hendrycks, Yoshua Bengio, and Max Tegmark released a paper proposing a quantifiable AGI framework based on the Cattell-Horn-Carroll (CHC) theory of human intelligence. The framework evaluates AI across ten cognitive domains and assigns an 'AGI Score' (0–100%). Current models show uneven performance: GPT-4 scores 27%, and GPT-5 (expected 2025) is projected at 58%. A major deficit is long-term memory storage, near 0%, causing AI systems to 're-learn' context in each interaction. The paper is available at agidefinition.ai. Additional updates include OpenAI releasing Sora 2 and a TikTok-style app, Microsoft and Anthropic hiring Rishi Sunak as advisors, Anthropic open-sourcing Petri for AI audits, and concerns over Unitree humanoid robot exploits. The Newsletter also notes California Governor Newsom signed SB-53, CAISI evaluated Deepseek’s models, and the Select Committee on the CCP found U.S.-allied firms selling semiconductor equipment to China.
Original language: en
Publish date: October 16, 2025 06:06 PM
Source:[Maya Farber Brodsky](https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/qLZnXYei62HdXGNnx/aisn-64-new-agi-definition-and-senate-bill-would-establish)

**China's latest round of rare-earth export controls gives the country dominion over precious resources  --  regulations have far-reaching implications for the semiconductor industry**
China has expanded its export control regime to include five heavy rare-earth elements—erbium, europium, holmium, thulium, and ytterbium—along with their alloys, oxides, compounds, and finished materials, effective from early November 2025. The controls now extend beyond raw materials to cover products and devices containing Chinese-origin rare earths if the value of those materials exceeds 0.1%, requiring dual-use export licenses from China's Ministry of Commerce. The regulations also encompass over 20 types of rare-earth processing equipment, including centrifugal extraction units, acid-resistant roasting kilns, electrolytic furnaces, and crystal-growth furnaces, as well as mining reagents, separation chemicals, and mineral feedstock. This move solidifies China’s dominance over the global rare-earth supply chain, including mining, refining, and application technologies. The rules prohibit exports to military users, entities on Chinese watch lists, and end uses involving weapons of mass destruction or terrorism. Critically, China’s Ministry of Commerce will review license applications for advanced logic chips (14nm and below), 3D NAND memory (256-layer+), and AI technologies with potential military applications, allowing Beijing to restrict materials to global chipmakers like TSMC and Micron. This marks a strategic shift from being a supplier to a global watchdog over rare-earth use. The controls are part of a multi-stage plan that now spans the entire semiconductor and electronics ecosystem—from wafer substrates to photonics and magnetics. While foreign companies may theoretically switch suppliers, doing so is costly and complex due to the need for requalification of processes and reliance on Chinese technology and know-how. The U.S. responded with a 100% tariff on China-made goods and a ban on 'critical software' for China-based entities. China’s control over both the physical materials and the means of production—including equipment, chemicals, and technical expertise—gives it unprecedented geopolitical leverage. Future expansions could include additional rare earths like neodymium or praseodymium, and potentially end-user controls, mirroring U.S. export enforcement models. The regulation, effective December 1, 2025, applies globally and signals China’s intent to govern the use of rare-earth materials worldwide.
Original language: en
Publish date: October 16, 2025 03:23 PM
Source:[Tom's Hardware](https://www.tomshardware.com/tech-industry/semiconductors/chinas-latest-round-of-rare-earth-export-controls-gives-the-country-dominion-over-precious-resources-regulations-have-far-reaching-implications-for-the-semiconductor-industry)

On October 16, 2025, major technology developments were reported globally. OpenAI CEO Sam Altman defended放宽 ChatGPT content restrictions, stating the company is not a 'global moral police' and will treat adult users as adults, allowing NSFW content under safety safeguards, similar to R-rated films. Honor unveiled its ROBOT PHONE, a robot-powered smartphone with a hidden mechanical arm, AI emotional awareness, and full-device orchestration, marking a shift toward 'silicon-based life partners,' with a 2026 debut in Barcelona. Huawei’s CEO He Xiaoqiang emphasized the strategic importance of building an independent semiconductor supply chain, noting the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area has become a core growth hub for semiconductors and ICs, housing over 10,000 companies and key players like Huawei and BYD. The struggle over NXP Semiconductor, involving Dutch 'four-not' restrictions and Chinese export controls, highlights geopolitical tensions in tech supply chains. OpenAI confirmed it will enable adult content generation in ChatGPT for verified adults by December, driven by competitive pressure and monetization needs. WeChat confirmed it no longer recycles inactive accounts since September 2025, preserving deceased users' Moments content, with no visitor tracking or editing features to preserve authenticity. In the 2025 food delivery market, JD, Meituan, and Alibaba engaged in intense competition—JD shifted from premium strategy to pragmatism after losses, Meituan focused on delivery efficiency amid ecosystem challenges, and Alibaba leveraged ecosystem synergy with heavy subsidies, leading to a transition from price wars to operational refinement, with potential threats from拼多多.

**China’s Export Controls Reveal U.S. Supply Chain Vulnerabilities in Critical Materials**
China has implemented new export controls on lithium batteries, graphite anode materials, and rare earth-related technologies, citing national security and non-proliferation obligations. These measures, announced on October 9, 2024, extend beyond raw materials to include critical equipment, processes, and services—marking a strategic upgrade in resource sovereignty. China dominates global production: over 90% of graphite for anodes, nearly 90% of rare earth oxides, and most NdFeB magnets. The controls target core sectors—clean energy, defense, and semiconductors—precisely those prioritized by the U.S. under the Inflation Reduction Act and CHIPS Act. The U.S. military relies on China for over 78% of materials used in its equipment, and rebuilding domestic rare earth refining capacity would take 5–10 years and billions in investment. China’s restrictions threaten U.S. AI infrastructure growth, with one assessment suggesting GDP growth could fall to under 0.1% in early 2025 without AI capital expansion. The U.S. electric vehicle revolution depends on China’s battery supply chain, with China processing two-thirds of global lithium and over 90% of graphite. Without Chinese technology and equipment, U.S. EV production would face higher costs, lower output, and delayed decarbonization. China’s export controls expose the fragility of U.S. industrial foundations, revealing deep dependency on Chinese supply chains in both green and digital transitions.
Original language: zh
Publish date: October 16, 2025 12:21 AM
Source:[guancha.cn](https://www.guancha.cn/WarwickPowell/2025_10_16_793453.shtml)

**China Expands Export Control on Rare Earth Minerals and More**
On October 9, 2025, China's Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) announced Decree No. 61 and Decree No. 62, significantly expanding export controls over the rare earth supply chain. Decree No. 61 targets foreign-made rare earth metals and products, while Decree No. 62 controls rare earth-related technology. The new rules extend China's export control authority to foreign-made products containing Chinese-origin rare earths or manufactured using Chinese technology, marking a major policy shift. MOFCOM cited cases of foreign entities circumventing controls by transferring Chinese-origin items to military and sensitive end-users, and illegally obtaining rare earth technology for use in sensitive sectors. The rules require foreign exporters to obtain a dual-use item export license from MOFCOM before exporting controlled items to countries outside China. Both initial Chinese exporters and subsequent foreign exporters must issue a compliance notification letter in MOFCOM’s unified format, informing customers that the product contains Chinese-origin rare earths and that further exports may require a Chinese license. The regulations bring nearly all rare earth-related technologies under control, including intellectual property licensing, investment, consulting, joint R&D, and employment. A new end-use restriction applies even to non-controlled items if they are used in foreign rare earth mining, smelting, separation, metal refining, magnetic material manufacturing, or recycling activities. Chinese individuals and organizations are prohibited from supporting such foreign activities without a license. Export applications for advanced semiconductor and AI-related end-uses are subject to case-by-case review by MOFCOM. The '50% Rule' denies export applications to importers and end-users on MOFCOM’s Export Control Watchlist or Concern List, including their subsidiaries and affiliates with 50% or more controlling equity. On the same day, MOFCOM issued four additional decrees restricting exports of rare earth manufacturing equipment, five specific rare earth minerals (Holmium, Erbium, Thulium, Europium, Ytterbium), lithium battery materials, artificial graphite anode materials, and superhard materials, and placed 14 companies on China’s Unreliable Entity List. The rules reflect a strategic effort to counter circumvention and safeguard national security.
Original language: en
Publish date: October 16, 2025 12:00 AM
Source:[The National Law Review - A Free To Use Nationwide Database of Legal Publications](https://natlawreview.com/article/china-expands-export-control-rare-earth-minerals-and-more)

**The Washington Post: China Now Leads the U.S. in Open-Source AI Development**
According to an analysis by The Washington Post, China is now leading the United States in the development of open-source artificial intelligence (AI) technologies, despite the U.S. having historically dominated the AI race. While American companies like OpenAI (ChatGPT) and Google (Gemini) are widely regarded as leaders in proprietary AI tools, Chinese firms are surpassing them in open AI models. In 2024, the best open AI models were primarily U.S.-based, but by 2025, all top open models were由中国制造. On LMArena, a blind-testing platform for AI outputs, Chinese models from companies like Alibaba and DeepSeek outperformed U.S. models from OpenAI and Meta. Hugging Face, a leading AI model-sharing platform, reported that DeepSeek’s open model received 12.8k upvotes—double the 6.3k for Meta’s top Llama model—while OpenAI ranked fifth with 4.0k. Irene Solaiman, Hugging Face’s Chief Policy Officer, noted that Chinese companies are more prolific in releasing high-quality models. Although OpenAI’s latest open model ranked ahead of DeepSeek in tests by Artificial Analysis, Solaiman emphasized that Chinese firms are also leading in open-source tools for image and video generation. The article highlights concerns in the U.S. over losing ground in open AI, prompting initiatives like the ATOM project (American Truly Open Models) to develop competitive open models. Meta’s Mark Zuckerberg, while advocating for open AI in 2023, later cautioned about 'carefully selecting' what to open-source, signaling a shift toward retaining proprietary advantages. The debate centers on whether open AI fosters innovation and global leadership or risks ceding strategic control to competitors.
Original language: zh
Publish date: October 15, 2025 11:55 PM
Source:[凤凰网（凤凰新媒体）](https://tech.ifeng.com/c/8nSvYiNNm5W)

**Global Tech: Trade Tensions Resurge — How Investors Should Respond**
In an unexpected escalation, the United States threatened to impose tariffs of up to 100% on Chinese imports in response to China's new export controls on rare earth elements and other critical raw materials. The U.S. will implement new export restrictions on products including semiconductor design software starting November 1, 2025. Despite this renewed trade tension between the world’s two largest economies, DBS Group maintains that the recent developments are short-term obstacles rather than signs of structural deterioration in the global trade framework. Consequently, DBS continues to maintain a positive outlook on global technology, AI-driven themes, and Asian markets excluding Japan. Market volatility has impacted tech-related firms, with the Nasdaq dropping 3.6% following the escalation. However, DBS remains optimistic due to the long-term strength of AI applications, particularly the 'sovereign AI' trend—where governments are accelerating AI deployment by investing in advanced technologies, semiconductor capacity, AI infrastructure, cloud networks, application innovation, cybersecurity, and uninterrupted power. The self-reinforcing capital ecosystem, prevalent among U.S. mega-cap tech firms, is seen as a model that governments may actively encourage to speed up critical infrastructure development. Leading semiconductor supply chain companies have been proactively diversifying their operations and revenue structures, driven significantly by increasingly strict U.S. export controls. DBS tracking of six major semiconductor and IC design firms shows that revenue from China fell from nearly 40% in 2018 to about 22% in 2024. This strategic shift—whether voluntary or externally driven—has reduced dependence on a single market. If Trump administration policies lead to stricter export controls or a complete ban on Chinese exports, these now more diversified companies are expected to experience manageable impacts on growth and fundamentals.

**SB 243: California Enacts New AI Law to Protect Youth from Harmful Chatbot Interactions**
California has passed SB 243, a new law regulating AI chatbots to protect youth and vulnerable adults. The law mandates that AI chatbots must be clearly identifiable as such and prohibits them from impersonating medical professionals, therapists, or other experts—practices previously reported to have occurred. The law specifically targets minors, who are more susceptible to harmful advice due to lack of experience, though protections extend to vulnerable adults as well. Key provisions include mandatory age verification systems, with OpenAI planning to implement one for ChatGPT starting December 2025, which will also unlock adult-only features like erotic conversations. Chatbots must log conversations that veer into dangerous territory, provide resources for help, prompt users to take breaks, block inappropriate content for minors, and warn users about risks before use. The law also strengthens penalties for AI-generated deepfake pornography and holds AI providers liable for damages. The law applies broadly to major providers like Meta, OpenAI, xAI, Google, and specialized platforms such as Character.ai and Replika, which allow users to create personalized AI companions—criticized for potential harm to children. The law was prompted by incidents including a 16-year-old’s suicide allegedly supported by ChatGPT and a 13-year-old girl’s case involving Character.ai, along with leaked documents showing Meta’s chatbots engaging in romantic conversations with minors. SB 243 follows California’s earlier AI law, SB 53, which focused on transparency. While other U.S. states are considering similar legislation, former President Donald Trump previously opposed AI regulation, citing concerns about U.S. competitiveness with China in the AI race. The law takes effect in January 2026.

**U.S. Lawmakers Warn of China’s $38 Billion Semiconductor Equipment Purchases, Call for Full Export Ban**
The U.S. House Select Committee on the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) released a 52-page report titled 'Selling the Forges of the Future' on October 8, 2025, revealing that Chinese entities legally purchased approximately $38 billion worth of semiconductor manufacturing equipment (SME) in 2024—up 66% from 2022. This accounted for 39% of the combined sales of the five leading SME suppliers: ASML (Netherlands), Tokyo Electron (TEL, Japan), KLA (U.S.), Applied Materials (U.S.), and Lam Research (Lam Research, U.S.). Committee Chair John Moolenaar stated that Western equipment manufacturers are sacrificing U.S. national security for profit, warning that continued exports risk undermining America’s technological and military edge. Democratic lead Raja Krishnamoorthi emphasized the absurdity of selling tools to produce chips used in military modernization and human rights abuses. The report identifies four national security threats from China’s SME procurement: military applications in 'intelligent warfare' relying on AI and advanced computing; efforts to build a vertically integrated semiconductor industry to withstand future export controls; economic dominance in both traditional and advanced chip production; and the use of AI for domestic repression and exporting 'digital authoritarianism.' The committee urges U.S. allies to align export controls with American restrictions, implement broad 'country-wide controls' to prevent circumvention, establish a whistleblower program, increase resources for the Department of Commerce’s Bureau of Industry and Security (BIS) and the State Department, and impose a full ban on SME component exports to China. The report warns equipment makers to view China and its national champions as long-term threats, not valuable customers.

**Export Controls Have Gaps: U.S. Report Finds Chinese Firms Still Purchasing Semiconductor Equipment at Scale**
A report by the U.S. House Select Committee on China, released on October 7, 2025, reveals that Chinese companies purchased approximately $38 billion in semiconductor manufacturing equipment from five major global suppliers—Applied Materials, KLA, Lam Research Corporation (U.S.), ASML (Netherlands), and Tokyo Electron Ltd (Japan)—in 2024, a 66% increase from 2022. These purchases accounted for 39% of the combined global revenue of these firms, with most transactions involving Chinese state-owned enterprises linked to the People's Liberation Army, intelligence agencies, and Huawei-affiliated companies. Although the equipment sold was not always the most advanced, many still contributed to China’s development of advanced chip manufacturing capabilities. The report highlights that current export controls are ineffective due to loopholes: while the most advanced equipment is banned, less advanced but still useful equipment can still be exported with permits. Additionally, after companies are added to the U.S. Entity List, new affiliated entities often emerge that are not yet sanctioned and can continue purchasing U.S. equipment. The report also notes a disparity between U.S. and non-U.S. firms: American companies face stricter restrictions than their foreign counterparts, who can still sell to listed Chinese firms. The committee’s chairman, Republican John Moolenaar, warned that allowing China access to critical semiconductor equipment would lead to U.S. defeat in the technological arms race. Democrat Raja Krishnamoorthi stated that selling equipment to China enables military modernization and human rights abuses, and emphasized the need for allied cooperation to maintain U.S. leadership in semiconductor manufacturing technology. The committee recommends expanding export bans beyond individual companies, aligning allied controls with U.S. standards, and establishing a new whistleblower export control program. According to Craig Singleton of the Foundation for Defense of Democracies, China is attempting to reshape global supply chains, turning niche equipment markets into new battlegrounds. Tokyo Electron’s U.S. CEO Mark Dougherty acknowledged a decline in sales to China due to new regulations, but stressed the need for stronger U.S.-Japan coordination, noting that 'the result the U.S. wants has not yet been achieved.' Applied Materials and Lam Research did not respond to requests for comment; ASML and KLA said they needed to review the report before commenting.

**The risks of export controls on AI chips**
US export controls on advanced AI chips, particularly those from Nvidia and AMD, have fundamentally reshaped semiconductor design and global supply chains. Since 2018, the US Department of Commerce’s Bureau of Industry and Security (BIS) has imposed strict limits on performance, memory bandwidth, and interconnect speeds to restrict China’s access to cutting-edge AI hardware. These regulations led to the creation of downgraded, export-compliant variants such as the Nvidia A800 (400 GBps interconnect bandwidth vs. 600 GBps on the A100), H800 (300 GBps vs. 900 GBps on the H100), and later the H20, which met updated 2023 performance and density caps. These chips were intentionally crippled via firmware, clock adjustments, and reduced memory speeds—turning engineering into compliance. The policy has driven Chinese companies like Huawei to surge in demand for their Ascend 910 series, while European stakeholders, alarmed by US restrictions—including proposed 2025 rules that would have extended export limits to EU allies—began planning to de-Americanize their supply chains. Although the US withdrew the controversial 'AI Diffusion Rule' in mid-2025 and resumed limited sales of H20 and AMD MI308 to China under special licenses, the long-term consequences include fractured global trust, accelerated development of rival ecosystems, and a shift in R&D investment from US firms to Chinese competitors. The result is a paradox: policies meant to maintain technological dominance may instead be fueling innovation in rival nations, undermining long-term US leverage. As one analysis notes, 'When policy, rather than physics, dictates chip specifications, innovation suffers.'

**Moolenaar pushes AI chip export limits to secure U.S. edge over China**
U.S. Rep. John Moolenaar (R‑MI) wrote a letter to Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick on Aug. 25 urging the adoption of a rolling technical threshold (RTT) approach to AI‑chip exports to China. The approach would allow U.S. firms to sell chips that are only marginally better than the most advanced chips China can produce domestically, thereby extending Chinese dependence on U.S. hardware while limiting China’s frontier AI development. Moolenaar said the policy should cap China’s aggregate AI compute at 10 percent of the U.S. level, a move he argues is essential for enduring U.S. AI dominance. He warned that China’s technology proliferation could also empower Russia, Iran, and proxy groups, noting that Iran ‘will be eager to take advantage of PRC‑enabled AI capabilities.’ The letter emphasizes that export controls must balance protecting U.S. semiconductor companies, maintaining U.S. hardware dominance, and limiting China’s AI capabilities. Moolenaar added that selling chips directly to Chinese firms can keep them reliant on U.S. hardware, but allowing them to acquire even moderately better chips would undermine U.S. hyperscalers such as Google, Microsoft, Amazon, and frontier labs like OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, xAI, and Meta. The proposed RTT approach, he said, would give U.S. AI hardware companies a clear advantage in the Chinese market through both direct sales and cloud access, providing clarity for the commercial sector and national‑security community about U.S. export‑control objectives.

summary:
Across a range of expert perspectives—including export control law, policy diffusion, national security, international relations, and technonationalism—there is strong consensus that the probability of the US enacting export controls on some generative AI software before the end of 2025 is high. The primary drivers cited are the rapid escalation of the US-China technological and trade rivalry, with direct tit-for-tat actions (China expanding rare earth and AI-related technology controls, and the US responding with new tariffs and explicit plans for export controls on 'critical software'), legislative and bipartisan political pressure within the US, and historical precedent where the US adopted new export controls quickly in response to rising threats. Multiple experts reference recent credible news reports indicating that the US is preparing or has already proposed export restrictions that could encompass generative AI software, with some mentioning that such controls could be made effective as soon as November 2025. 

Countervailing factors include enforcement and definitional difficulties (controlling software is more complex than hardware), economic and industry lobbying from major US tech companies, and the global proliferation of open-source models that may undermine the effectiveness of such controls. However, most experts argue that these are unlikely to prevent at least some formal, targeted export controls from being enacted when national security and political imperatives are high, especially if the controls cover export to China or other listed adversaries and do not require comprehensive bans.

Final probabilities assigned by experts mostly range from 78% to 91%, with a single slightly lower outlier (68%) reflecting continued uncertainty about bureaucratic and industry resistance. The weighted average is around the mid-80s. Typical envisioned scenarios for a YES outcome involve the Commerce Department or US executive branch formally adding generative AI software (at least above certain capability thresholds or for specified restricted countries) to the export control regime before December 31, 2025. A NO outcome generally presupposes significant delay due to lobbying, technical ambiguity, or internal policy fragmentation. Overall, the group expects formal US export controls on some generative AI software to be enacted prior to 2026.
